Comment: Tier three manufacturer.  Already been seeing an uptick in orders from our customers who used to outsource their production overseas but would rather not deal with the tariffs now.  Whether this will stick is anybody's guess, but so far the tariffs have been good for business here, even if they've been a bit of a pain due to dealing with new suppliers and whatnot.  But that would've happened regardless if production at rebased some other way anyways.  It's a nice change after four years of having to cut hours and layoff people.  Outside of work, nothing has changed at all but except now I have to listen to my parents complain about how much they've lost in their retirement and how they won't be able to do as much travelling in the next few years.  I love my folks, and I sympathize with them... But having spent up until only recently living paycheck to paycheck and being closer to retirement age than not now... I fully expect to get at most a couple shitty years off work before I die, not twenty plus years of retirement travelling wherever I feel like it... So its tough to sympathize too much.  So I guess the tldr is that my job feels more secure than it ever did in the past four years, but I'm in a blue collar job so that probably makes the difference, and I have to listen to privileged people complain about losing their privilege.

Given the above information, it is appropriate to find frustration in OP implying that everyone who uses this site and is nervous or ‚Äúuncertain‚Äù about the current state of things is being a fear-monger since OP hasn‚Äôt personally been affected by the economy taking a dive. Author: whatweshouldcallyou

Comment: Either people don't understand or leftists are downvoting you because they don't like reality.¬†   Sell price doesn't matter until you're selling (retiring). Having a buy price that's temporarily low is great if you aren't retiring any time soon. Assuming you continue to contribute the same dollar amount to buying shares, you'll be getting more shares for your money and they'll be worth more later.   Say you normally contribute $100 per paycheck to your 401k. Say shares normally cost $10. Normally you get 10 shares. But the market is down and shares are only $5. Now you get 20 shares per paycheck! When the market returns to normal, your 20 shares are now worth $200.   It would have been great to be able to convert your volatile shares to safe government bonds before the market dipped, but not having been able to predict it accurately enough the best thing to do now is to buy shares while they're cheap.
